headline: Coty Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining us. On today's call are Bart Becht, Chairman and Interim CEO; and Patrice de Talhouët, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Before we begin, I would like to remind you that many of our comments m
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining us. On today's call are Bart Becht, Chairman and Interim CEO; and Patrice de Talhouët, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. 
Before we begin, I would like to remind you that many of our comments may contain forward-looking statements. Please refer to our press release and our reports filed with the SEC, where you will find factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from these forward-looking statements. 
All discussions of net revenues are on a like-for-like basis. In addition, except where noted, the discussion of our financial results and our expectations do not reflect certain nonrecurring and other charges. You can find the bridge from GAAP to non-GAAP results in the reconciliation tables in the earnings release. 
I will now turn the call over to Bart.

headline: Coty Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kevin. This morning, we'll provide you with a brief update on the expected merger with the P&G Specialty Beauty Business, other corporate developments and Q2 and year-to-date results. Then Patrice and I will be pleased to take your questions.
componenttext:
Thank you, Kevin. This morning, we'll provide you with a brief update on the expected merger with the P&G Specialty Beauty Business, other corporate developments and Q2 and year-to-date results. Then Patrice and I will be pleased to take your questions. 
Our efforts right now are all about creating a very healthy platform for Coty to become the strong leader and challenger in the beauty industry that we aim for it to be. This quarter, we made good progress on that objective, both on the merger acquisition front and the underlying Coty business side. 
Starting with the core Coty business. Q2 showed continued improvement in business fundamentals. Coty revenue trends remain muted with a 1% like-for-like decline, and we do expect the Q2 trend to continue for the remainder of the fiscal year as we continue to rationalize nonstrategic product lines and businesses. However, and encouragingly, power brands experienced solid mid-single-digit growth in the second quarter, very much helped by our strategy of focusing and investing in these key brands. 
We also continue to show strong momentum in driving profit and cash flow generation. Our year-to-date operating profit grew high single digits, with adjusted operating income growing 13% at constant currency, an impressive growth in operating margin. At the same time, our strong networking capital improvement contributed to significant growth in free cash flow generation. These results show that we can continue to build a healthier and better business despite subdued revenue growth performance. 
On the merger and acquisition side, we've made good progress on our Bourjois acquisition. As of today, the local Bourjois businesses have been integrated within Coty local subsidiaries. Also, Bourjois and Coty processes as well as information technology are now fully aligned We continue to see good growth opportunities for this brand and remain confident that it will be margin-accretive to our call of business in fiscal 2017. 
Since announcing the acquisition of Beamly in the second quarter, these top-holding leaders in this Digital Marketing company have started to engage and work with the Coty brands on several digital campaigns. We are confident, by bringing in Beamly's cutting-edge digital engagement platform in house, we will continue to strengthen Coty's marketing and branding efforts. 
In addition, we announced on February 1 the completion of the acquisition of the Hypermarcas Beauty & Personal Care business. As a reminder, Hypermarcas is a highly profitable business, with operating margins above Coty levels. This transaction will strengthen Coty's exposure to Brazil, which is one of the largest and growing beauty markets in the world. 
We believe it will also provide an excellent platform to integrate the existing small Coty business into sizable P&G Specialty Beauty Business in Brazil. 
And as announced last week, we signed a new fragrance license agreement with Tiffany & Co., an international renowned jeweler, which we believe will further strengthen our future position as the industry leader in fragrances. 
On the P&G Specialty Beauty Business merger, we confirmed the transfer of 10 P&G fragrance licenses, including global powerhouses such as Hugo Boss, Gucci and Lacoste. We are making excellent progress to close the P&G Specialty Beauty Business merger in the second half of calendar 2016, and we are happy to report that we have received antitrust approval from the U.S., among other countries. And we are actively engaged in discussions with the EU antitrust authorities. We have also materially advanced structuring and staffing our future organization and are well-advanced in setting up the teams and work stream supporting our IT system requirements and blueprinting the integration plan for the combined businesses. 
And as I discussed on the last call, we believe the new consumer-centric and category-focused organizational structure, our strong brand portfolio, together with our new leadership team, will position Coty well to realize its ambition of becoming a true leader and challenger in the beauty industry and drive profitable growth and shareholder value over time. 
I will now hand over the call to Patrice.

headline: Coty Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bart, and good morning, everyone. Total Q2 net revenues declined 1% like-for-like, with an improvement in the Fragrance segment trends compared to Q1 and a solid core Cosmetics growth in spite of the decline in the U.S. main market. I'm happy t
componenttext:
Thank you, Bart, and good morning, everyone. Total Q2 net revenues declined 1% like-for-like, with an improvement in the Fragrance segment trends compared to Q1 and a solid core Cosmetics growth in spite of the decline in the U.S. main market. I'm happy to report that fiscal year to date, the adjusted gross margin increased a very strong 130 basis points to 60.9%, reflecting our continuous effort in driving supply chain efficiencies and reducing discounting activity. 
We keep on building a better business even in the phase out soft topline trends, with adjusted operating income growing 5% fiscal year-to-date, with a much more substantial 13% increase at constant currency. The year-to-date adjusted operating margin at actual rates grew 160 basis points, with meaningful margin increase in Color Cosmetics up 330 basis points and Skin & Body Care up 420 basis points. The Fragrance segment margin increased 20 basis points to 20.2%. 
As we discussed on the last call, given the market conditions in our global footprint, FX continued to pressure our revenues and operating income. Fiscal year-to-date, FX lowered net revenues and operating income by over 600 basis points. 
Our year-to-date adjusted diluted EPS was $0.98 compared to $0.73 in the prior year, reflecting, in part, the benefit from the favorable tax of $113.3 million this year compared to a $32.5 million settlement in the prior period. Our Global Efficiency Program remains on track, as we have recognized cumulative savings of approximately $170 million through the second quarter of fiscal 2016, driven by fixed cost reduction, indirect procurement savings, footprint consolidation and more streamlined operations in China. As a reminder, we expect to generate savings of approximately $270 million through fiscal '17. 
On the balance sheet, as a reminder, we closed on $4.5 billion credit facility this quarter to refinance existing Coty debt with new borrowings subject to longer maturities. As of today, we have [indiscernible] approximately 40% of our outstanding net floating rate debt into FX rates at an owning cost below 3%, with an average maturities between 3 and 5 years. 
In addition, certain lenders have committed to loan up to $4.5 billion with P&G, which is expected to be conveyed to Coty in connection with the expected merger with the P&G Specialty Beauty Business. 
With regard to the merger, the initial filing of our registration statement in connection with the transaction is expected to be filed in April. This registration document will include [indiscernible] information for the Beauty Brands we're acquiring from P&G through December 31, 2015. 
Our strong balance sheet and cash flow generation allows us to continue to advance on our strategic and financial objectives. 
I'm very happy to report that fiscal year-to-date, we generated $517.1 million in operating cash flow and $438.7 million in free cash flow, each up over $160 million versus the prior year. Supported by these strong cash flow generation, we completed our $700 million share buyback program during the second quarter. In total, this fiscal year, we repurchased approximately 26 million Class A shares, and we also returned almost $90 million of cash to shareholders as dividends. 
We also announced this morning that the Board has authorized an incremental $500 million of share repurchase program. We will remain opportunistic in the way we use this authorization. It further supports our commitment to return cash to shareholder. 
Finally, on February 1, we completed the acquisition of Hypermarcas Beauty & Personal Care business, which we believe, as Bart said, will be a great platform to integrate our current and future business in Brazil. We are very excited to expand our footprint in Brazil with this portfolio of leading brands. 
The execution of the Bourjois acquisition, in line with our expectations, as well as the timely closing of the Hypermarcas acquisition, demonstrates our ability to successfully execute on our M&A growth strategy. 
Thank you. I will now open the call for questions.

componenttextpreview: Yes. So this will be an ongoing process, and it will be reviewed again as part of the P&G merger because then clearly, we will have an enlarged portfolio, and we're going to have, again, that reflects in terms of how we deal with the brand portfolio postm
componenttext: Yes. So this will be an ongoing process, and it will be reviewed again as part of the P&G merger because then clearly, we will have an enlarged portfolio, and we're going to have, again, that reflects in terms of how we deal with the brand portfolio postmerger. So when I say rationalization of the portfolio, I really am referring to several items. First, there is a rationalization of a very small brands, which is in the tail of the portfolio. But there's also a discontinuation of certain lines, business lines or product lines of brands, in particular, when they're in places where we don't really want to see them. I'll give you a classic example. Selling OPI, hardware stores is probably not the smartest idea we could do as a company, which is passionate about beauty. And so there is also a rationalization of some businesses in locations where it shouldn't be. So it is both basically a rationalization of small brands and taking out kind of like business situations and to clean that up. And that is an ongoing effort, which will not stop in this quarter or the next quarter and will continue postmerger.

componenttext: So clearly, on power brands, and as you all know, our strategy is very much to continue to focus and invest in these brands behind key innovations. And that's clearly what you're seeing in the second quarter. Having said that, there also is an impact in terms of phasing of launches. As you will know, in the Beauty Business, but in particular, in the Fragrance side of the business, which is a substantial chunk of Coty, launch timing around Fragrances substantial impact the growth trends. So last year, we had a big launch around Calvin Klein in the first quarter, which we didn't have this year. I believe we didn't have the same side of innovation. Having said that, on the other side, Marc Jacobs Decadence is very much hits the second quarter. So you are always going to see some fluctuation in the growth rate on the power brands. Having said that, clearly, we're very hopeful that we will continue to grow our power brands, in particular, as we rationalize a lot of the businesses outside of power brands.

componenttext: So on the working capital, John, as you know, I'm coming from a company who is familiar with the negative working capital. So -- and we are not yet there. So we need to continue that journey. This being said, it is true that the payables have been the biggest component in the improvement so far. I think there is still some room for improvement in the payables. Now what we really need to tackle is first, the GSO. There is some room for improvement in the couple of regions. And second, in a more fundamental base is the inventory level. And this is, as you know, more long-term process, which is really about forecast accuracy, rationalization of the possible that we'll definitely have in that regard. So that's more in the long term. But we are not yet as you're working capital becoming within reach of that target, that we're not yet there. And I think there's going to be some further improvement.

componenttext: Yes. Before we start talking about more deals, as you know, we have a few basically to execute at the moment. So I'm going to refrain from commenting on new deals. The Hypermarcas business is really critical business enabler, both basically in the P&G transaction as well as to establish a long-term interesting business in Brazil. And the reason for that is very, very straightforward. The Coty business is very, very small, and therefore, has a very critical mass infrastructure. The P&G business is a carveout, and as a result, has a very large of a soft critical mass infrastructure. Just to give me some perspective, the P&G transaction in Brazil would have come with one salesperson. I don't have to tell you that that's not good enough to run a Brazilian business. So the Hypermarcas organization is the full sledge infrastructure business. It has everything. It has a state-of-the-art manufacturing facility and logistics infrastructure. It has also state-of-the-art basically go-to-market infrastructure and a management team, which has proven to be successful in the market from a market share point of view. So as we speak, we are starting to degrade the Coty business into Hypermarcas. And then once that's done, they will get ready to integrate the P&G business. So Hypermarcas is really the main body that is going to be used in order to integrate and the Coty business and the P&G business, rather than Hypermarcas not integrated in Coty. Really, Coty is being integrated into Hypermarcas. Clearly,  it gets renamed Coty, but just to be across the clear, from a critical mass but any, that's where the point of gravity lies, and that's very much of an enabler to get deals done as well as to have a healthy business platform going forward.

headline: Coty Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say it is main accelerator. In markets like Brazil, if you don't have your own manufacturing infrastructure and your own go-to-market infrastructure, it is very difficult to be successful as many multinational company because you cannot basically
componenttext: I would say it is main accelerator. In markets like Brazil, if you don't have your own manufacturing infrastructure and your own go-to-market infrastructure, it is very difficult to be successful as many multinational company because you cannot basically work with third parties in these 2 areas. So it is a massive accelerator. The fact that Coty doesn't have its own manufacturing infrastructure and has a substandard go-to-market infrastructure, the fact that the P&G business does not really have a local manufacturing infrastructure postdeal and doesn't really have a good go-to-market infrastructure is seriously handicapping just taking over the P&G business. So it really is a massive accelerator for us. The other good thing about Hypermarcas is that it's a proven management team. They're gaining as we speak in practically every category that they operate. And so I genuinely believe that this is a massive accelerator for us to be successful even in not in the long term, even in the longer term in Brazil. Clearly, the first job is to absorb these new business -- absorb Coty and then the P&G business. That's the first job. And then shortly thereafter, I would hope that we are going to see a acceleration in terms of the whole platform.

componenttext: So in terms of the nail category, clearly, there are 2 very distinct category segments. One is what happens at retail, and the other one's what happens at salons. componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining us. On today's call are Bart Becht, Chairman and Interim CEO; and Patrice de Talhouët, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. 
Before we begin, I would like to remind you that many of our comments may contain forward-looking statements. Please refer to our press release and our reports filed with the SEC, where you will find factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from these forward-looking statements. 
All discussions of net revenues are on a like-for-like basis. In addition, except where noted, the discussion of our financial results and our expectations do not reflect certain nonrecurring and other charges. You can find the bridge from GAAP to non-GAAP results in the reconciliation tables in the earnings release.
I will now turn the call over to Bart.

headline: Coty Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kevin. This morning, we'll provide you with a brief update on the expected merger with the P&G Specialty Beauty Business, other corporate developments and Q2 and year-to-date results. Then Patrice and I will be pleased to take your questions.
componenttext:
Thank you, Kevin. This morning, we'll provide you with a brief update on the expected merger with the P&G Specialty Beauty Business, other corporate developments and Q2 and year-to-date results. Then Patrice and I will be pleased to take your questions. 
Our efforts right now are all about creating a very healthy platform for Coty to become the strong leader and challenger in the beauty industry that we aim for it to be. This quarter, we made good progress on that objective, both on the merger acquisition front and the underlying Coty business side.
Starting with the core Coty business. Q2 showed continued improvement in business fundamentals. Coty revenue trends remain muted with a 1% like-for-like decline, and we do expect the Q2 trend to continue for the remainder of the fiscal year as we continue to rationalize nonstrategic product lines and businesses. However, and encouragingly, power brands experienced solid mid-single-digit growth in the second quarter, very much helped by our strategy of focusing and investing in these key brands.
We also continue to show strong momentum in driving profit and cash flow generation. Our year-to-date operating profit grew high single digits, with adjusted operating income growing 13% at constant currency, an impressive growth in operating margin. At the same time, our strong networking capital improvement contributed to significant growth in free cash flow generation. These results show that we can continue to build a healthier and better business despite subdued revenue growth performance.
On the merger and acquisition side, we've made good progress on our Bourjois acquisition. As of today, the local Bourjois businesses have been integrated within Coty local subsidiaries. Also, Bourjois and Coty processes as well as information technology are now fully aligned We continue to see good growth opportunities for this brand and remain confident that it will be margin-accretive to our call of business in fiscal 2017. 
Since announcing the acquisition of Beamly in the second quarter, these top-holding leaders in this Digital Marketing company have started to engage and work with the Coty brands on several digital campaigns. We are confident, by bringing in Beamly's cutting-edge digital engagement platform in-house. We will continue to strengthen Coty's marketing and branding efforts.
In addition, we announced on February 1 the completion of the acquisition of the Hypermarcas Beauty & Personal Care business. As a reminder, Hypermarcas is a highly profitable business, with operating margins above Coty levels. This transaction will strengthen Coty's exposure to Brazil, which is one of the largest and growing beauty markets in the world.  We believe it will also provide an excellent platform to integrate the existing small Coty business into sizable P&G Specialty Beauty Business in Brazil. 
And as announced last week, we signed a new fragrance license agreement with Tiffany & Co., an international renowned jeweler, which we believe will further strengthen our future position as the industry leader in fragrances.
On the P&G Specialty Beauty Business merger, we confirm the transfer of 10 P&G fragrance licenses, including global powerhouses such as Hugo Boss, Gucci and Lacoste. We are making excellent progress to close the P&G Specialty Beauty Business merger in the second half of calendar 2016, and we are happy to report that we have received antitrust approval from the U.S., among other countries. And we are actively engaged in discussions with the EU antitrust authorities. We have also materially advanced on structuring and staffing our future organization and are well advanced in setting up the teams and work stream supporting our IT system requirements and blueprinting the integration plan for the combined businesses. 
And as I discussed on the last call, we believe the new consumer-centric and category-focused organizational structure, our strong brand portfolio, together with our new leadership team, will position Coty well to realize its ambition of becoming a true leader and challenger in the beauty industry and drive profitable growth and shareholder value over time. 
I will now hand over the call to Patrice.

headline: Coty Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bart, and good morning, everyone. Total Q2 net revenues declined 1% like-for-like, with an improvement in the Fragrance segment trends compared to Q1, and a solid Color Cosmetics segment growth with in spite of the decline in the U.S. main mark
componenttext:
Thank you, Bart, and good morning, everyone. Total Q2 net revenues declined 1% like-for-like, with an improvement in the Fragrance segment trends compared to Q1, and a solid Color Cosmetics segment growth with in spite of the decline in the U.S. main market. I'm happy to report that fiscal year to date, the adjusted gross margin increased a very strong 130 basis points to 60.9%, reflecting our continuous effort in driving supply chain efficiencies and reducing discounting activity.
We keep on building a better business even in the phase of soft topline trends, with adjusted operating income growing 5% fiscal year-to-date, with a much more substantial 13% increase at constant currency. The year-to-date adjusted operating margin at actual rates grew 160 basis points, with meaningful margin increase in Color Cosmetics up 330 basis points and Skin & Body Care up 420 basis points. The Fragrance segment margin increased 20 basis points to 20.2%.
As we discussed on the last call, given the market conditions in our global footprint, FX continued to pressure our revenues and operating income. Fiscal year-to-date, FX lowered net revenues and operating income by over 600 basis points. 
Our year-to-date adjusted diluted EPS was $0.98 compared to $0.73 in the prior year, reflecting, in part, the benefit from the favorable tax settlement  of $113.3 million this year compared to a $32.5 million settlement in the prior period. Our Global Efficiency program remains on track, as we have recognized cumulative savings of approximately $170 million through the second quarter of fiscal 2016, driven by fixed cost reduction, indirect procurement savings, footprint consolidation and more streamlined operations in China. As a reminder, we expect to generate savings of approximately $270 million through fiscal '17.
On the balance sheet, as a reminder, we closed on a $4.5 billion credit facility this quarter to refinance existing Coty debt with new borrowings subject to longer maturities. As of today, we have swapped approximately 40% of our outstanding net floating rate debt into fixed rates at an owning cost below 3%, with an average maturities between 3 and 5 years. 
In addition, certain lenders have committed to loan up to $4.5 billion, an affiliate of P&G, which is expected to be conveyed to Coty in connection with the expected merger with the P&G Specialty Beauty Business.
With regard to the merger, the initial filing of our registration statement in connection with the transaction is expected to be filed in April. This registration document will include historical financial information for the Beauty Brands we're acquiring from P&G through December 31, 2015.
Our strong balance sheet and cash flow generation allowed us to continue to advance on our strategic and financial objectives.
I'm very happy to report that fiscal year-to-date, we generated $517.1 million in operating cash flow and $438.7 million in free cash flow, each up over $160 million versus the prior year. Supported by these strong cash flow generation, we completed our $700 million share buyback program during the second quarter. In total, this fiscal year, we repurchased approximatively 26 million Class A shares, and we also returned almost $90 million of cash to shareholders as dividends.
We also announced this morning that the Board has authorized an incremental $500 million of share repurchase program. We will remain opportunistic in the way we use this authorization. It further supports our commitment to return cash to shareholder.
Finally, on February 1, we completed the acquisition of Hypermarcas Beauty & Personal Care business, which we believe, as Bart said, will be a great platform to integrate our current and future business in Brazil. We are very excited to expand our footprint in Brazil with this portfolio of leading brands. 
The execution of the Bourjois acquisition, in line with our expectations as well as the timely closing of the Hypermarcas acquisition demonstrate our ability to successfully execute on our M&A growth strategy.
Thank you. I will now open the call for questions.

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Bill Schmitz with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Coty Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you just comment about some of the disclosures in the P&G filings? I looked at their last 10-Q and it shows some like pretty sharp declines in both sales and profits in some of the acquired brands. So I'd just love some colors around like how much cur
componenttext: Can you just comment about some of the disclosures in the P&G filings? I looked at their last 10-Q and it shows some like pretty sharp declines in both sales and profits in some of the acquired brands. So I'd just love some colors around like how much currency impact to that, maybe some of the brands that P&G closed and are being transferred that might be in there. Any color would be appreciated.

headline: Coty Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks for the question, Bill. So while we cannot comment on the disclosure of our performance of the business that are not, today, a part of Coty, we do want to highlight a couple of points. So first, it is our understanding that the disclosure in t
componenttext: Yes, thanks for the question, Bill. So while we cannot comment on the disclosure of our performance of the business that are not, today, a part of Coty, we do want to highlight a couple of points. So first, it is our understanding that the disclosure in the public filings you referenced reflect the sales and profitability of the 47 brands that were part of the P&G's portfolio and now classified as discontinued operation, rather than the 41 brands that Coty would be acquiring as part of the planned merger. So 4 of the 47 brands have already been sold or discontinued by P&G. Second, we also understand the negative FX impacts accounted for a very substantial component of the reported decline in the sales of these 47 brands. Third, we also understand that the organic growth rate of the 41 brands we are acquiring is in line with the like-for-like trend that we are seeing in the Coty business, both for Q2 fiscal '16 and year-to-date. So I think this gives you a little bit more perspective and color around the disclosure.

headline: Coty Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's great. And then can you just talk about the Dolce & Gabbana and Christina Aguilera licenses? Sort of how big are they? Is there going to be like a purchase price adjustment as the color get moves? Anything you guys can provide in the public co
componenttext: Yes, that's great. And then can you just talk about the Dolce & Gabbana and Christina Aguilera licenses? Sort of how big are they? Is there going to be like a purchase price adjustment as the color get moves? Anything you guys can provide in the public context would also be appreciated.

headline: Coty Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We are not going to basically disclose that. I think it would be much better is to wait for the S-4 filing, which will happen in the second half of April because that will really provide the total scope of the business as we will be acquiring with al
componenttext: Yes. We are not going to basically disclose that. I think it would be much better is to wait for the S-4 filing, which will happen in the second half of April because that will really provide the total scope of the business as we will be acquiring with all the financial details. And then shortly after this disclosure, we'll provide an update also in terms of our financial perspective around the deal dynamics. But I would say to have a discussion just about Dolce & Gabbana today, we don't really think it's appropriate. I think it would be much better handled when we have all the facts on the table and then have a discussion about what we believe the deal will do for Coty going forward. So that also should happen end April, latest early May.

headline: Coty Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Also, to build on that on the potential adjustments, so as per the transaction agreement, you assume debt from the P&G Specialty Beauty Business will be adjusted downward to reflect the fact that 10 out of the 12 providable licenses, subject to regulatory
componenttext: Also, to build on that on the potential adjustments, so as per the transaction agreement, you assume debt from the P&G Specialty Beauty Business will be adjusted downward to reflect the fact that 10 out of the 12 providable licenses, subject to regulatory approval, are transferred in all the 12. These downward debt adjustment will be based using a specific and contractory pre-agreed formula that we will disclose at a later date.

headline: Coty Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great that does really help. And then just a follow-up on the SKU and brand rationalization. Can you just talk about how far along are you -- you are on that process and what the impact was, both in the quarter and year-to-date on organic growth, if
componenttext: Okay, great that does really help. And then just a follow-up on the SKU and brand rationalization. Can you just talk about how far along are you -- you are on that process and what the impact was, both in the quarter and year-to-date on organic growth, if you have it?

headline: Coty Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So this will be an ongoing process, and it will be reviewed again as part of the P&G merger because then clearly, we won't have an enlarged portfolio, and we're going to have, again, reflect in terms of how we deal with the brand portfolio postmerger
componenttext: Yes. So this will be an ongoing process, and it will be reviewed again as part of the P&G merger because then clearly, we won't have an enlarged portfolio, and we're going to have, again, reflect in terms of how we deal with the brand portfolio postmerger. So when I say rationalization of the portfolio, I really referring to several items. First, there is a rationalization of a very small brands, which is in the tail of the portfolio. But there's also a discontinuation of certain lines, business lines or product lines of brands, in particular, when they're in places where we don't really want to really see them. I'll give you a classic example. Selling OPI nail polish in hardware stores is probably not the smartest idea we could do as a company, which is passionate about beauty. And so there is also a rationalization of some businesses in locations where it shouldn't be. So it is both basically a rationalization of small brands and taking out kind of like business situations and to clean that up. And that is an ongoing effort, which will not stop in this quarter or the next quarter and will continue postmerger.

headline: Coty Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from John Faucher with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from John Faucher with JPMorgan.

headline: Coty Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Want to talk about this sequential improvement in the power brands and then sort of what necessarily do you think is driving that? How sustainable is it? Is it more of a stabilization? Or is this something where we could, you could see it getting better a
componenttext: Want to talk about this sequential improvement in the power brands and then sort of what necessarily do you think is driving that? How sustainable is it? Is it more of a stabilization? Or is this something where we could, you could see it getting better and better as we go through? And then a second question on the cash flow, which is the working capital appears to be coming a lot from working capital. I think, in particular, payables were better than what we had anticipated. And sort of okay, is that a new level? And should we continue to see further improvement in working capital?

headline: Coty Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So clearly, on power brands, and as you all know, our strategy is very much to continue to focus and invest in these brands behind key innovations. And that's clearly what you're seeing in the second quarter. Having said that, there also is an impact in t
componenttext: So clearly, on power brands, and as you all know, our strategy is very much to continue to focus and invest in these brands behind key innovations. And that's clearly what you're seeing in the second quarter. Having said that, there also is an impact in terms of phasing of launches. As you will know, in the Beauty Business, but in particular, in the Fragrance side of the business, which is substantial chunk of Coty, launch timings around Fragrances substantially impact the growth trends. So last year, we had a big launch around Calvin Klein in the first quarter, which we didn't have this year. At least, we didn't have the same size of innovation. Having said that, on the other side, Marc Jacobs Decadence very much hits the second quarter. So you are always going to see some fluctuation in the growth rate on the power brands. Having said that, clearly, we're very hopeful that we will continue to grow our power brands, in particular, as we rationalize a lot of the businesses outside of the power brands.

headline: Coty Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on the working capital, John, as you know, I'm coming from a company who is familiar with negative working capital. So -- and we are not yet there. So we need to continue that journey. These being said, it is true that the payables have been the bigges
componenttext: So on the working capital, John, as you know, I'm coming from a company who is familiar with negative working capital. So -- and we are not yet there. So we need to continue that journey. These being said, it is true that the payables have been the biggest component in the improvement so far. I think there is still some room for improvement in the payables. Now what we really need to tackle is first, the GSA. There is some room for improvement in the couple of regions. And second, on a more fundamental basis, the inventory level. And this is, as you know, more long-term process, which is really about forecast accuracy  rationalization of the password [ph] that we'll definitely have in that regard. So that's more in the long term. But we are not yet at zero working capital becoming within reach of that target, but we're not yet there. And I think there's going to be some further improvement.

headline: Coty Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Wendy Nicholson with Citi Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Wendy Nicholson with Citi Research.

headline: Coty Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry if I missed it, but could you walk through on sort of what contributed to the gross margin expansion in the quarter, how sustainable that is? Is it just cost savings? Is it more favorable mix? That kind of stuff. Because I was obviously pretty i
componenttext: I'm sorry if I missed it, but could you walk through on sort of what contributed to the gross margin expansion in the quarter, how sustainable that is? Is it just cost savings? Is it more favorable mix? That kind of stuff. Because I was obviously pretty impressed.

headline: Coty Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So the gross margin improvement is very sustainable in the sense that it's mainly coming from supply chain. And as you know, we have embarked into a Productivity program 3 years ago. And we have, on an annual basis, steady improvement from the suppl
componenttext: Sure. So the gross margin improvement is very sustainable in the sense that it's mainly coming from supply chain. And as you know, we have embarked into a Productivity program 3 years ago. And we have, on an annual basis, steady improvement from the supply chain. It's coming from procurement savings first. It's also coming from rationalization of the footprint and consolidation of the footprint that we continue to do. So these are very sustainable gross margin improvement. On top of that, there are $2 billion sitting between gross sales and net sales, and we are starting to tackle that with some [indiscernible] measurements. This is a long-term process, and we are really working on that. And I think there have been some improvement in that regard or so.

headline: Coty Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that gap is promotions and that kind of stuff, principally?
componenttext: And that gap is promotions and that kind of stuff, principally?

headline: Coty Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry, can you say that again?
componenttext: Sorry, can you say that again?

headline: Coty Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: The gap between the gross sales and the net sales is promotions and discounting and gift repurchase and that kind of stuff?
componenttext: The gap between the gross sales and the net sales is promotions and discounting and gift repurchase and that kind of stuff?

headline: Coty Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, there are basically historical discounts, which have been agreed with retailers. So it's always a combination of different buckets. And as you will know, even the discount structure depends very much on a country-by-country basis. It's not the same ac
componenttext: No, there are basically historical discounts, which have been agreed with retailers. So it's always a combination of different buckets. And as you will know, even the discount structure depends very much on a country-by-country basis. It's not the same across the globe. So there are promotional discounts in there. There are year-end rebates in there. There are contractual arrangements with retailers in there. So it's a variety basically of different components and even across the countries that we'd have to discuss with you country-by-country. It's simply the structure differs. If you're interested, we can have a discussion about this at some point in time, but it is quite involved discussion.

headline: Coty Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And is it fair to say the power brands generally are higher gross margin? Or is there more discounting that goes on with those power brands because they are growing faster and they require more investment?
componenttext: And is it fair to say the power brands generally are higher gross margin? Or is there more discounting that goes on with those power brands because they are growing faster and they require more investment?

headline: Coty Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say, on average, the power brands are -- that depends. It's not consistent across the power brands. Some of them definitely are higher margin, but there are also a few which are slightly lower margin than the average. So it's not basically consist
componenttext: I would say, on average, the power brands are -- that depends. It's not consistent across the power brands. Some of them definitely are higher margin, but there are also a few which are slightly lower margin than the average. So it's not basically consistent picture across. Not at this stage.

headline: Coty Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: So yes, indeed that you are right. There was some adjustment mechanism based on the working capital, and this is the reason why we had this adjustment.

componenttext: Got it. Okay. And then back on the debt adjustment for the Procter deal. I appreciate you're not wanting to talk about it. But is it fair to assume basically that when we're trying to adjust for [indiscernible] the S-4, we pre-agreed to multiples that the business will be worth, basically we get backed out, whatever that is per the disclosures as a reflection of anticipated EBITDA. headline: Coty Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we're not going to comment on that. We'll have another session on all the financials end of April or early May. And then a lot of this stuff will be clarified. Even at that point in time, there still will have to be discussion if we're going to disclo
componenttext: No, we're not going to comment on that. We'll have another session on all the financials end of April or early May. And then a lot of this stuff will be clarified. Even at that point in time, there still will have to be discussion if we're going to disclose the adjustment formula because that impacts, to some extent, the ability what happens to this brand on the P&G side. So we would have to get their agreement to disclose this. So what will be very clear from the S-4, which I think, is what you all will be looking for is, what is the scope and what is the structure, the financial structure of this business. So I think you all will be very happy when you see all the data. And I think the second part that you're going to get shortly thereafter is our perspective of what the financial impact is of combining the 2 businesses, which I think also will be what you're looking for. The one thing, which I'm not sure, we will have at that point in time, and I'm not saying we will not have it, but I just cannot tell you today, is the adjustment formula for the Dolce & Gabbana business not coming to us because that's something which would have to be agreed with P&G.

headline: Coty Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay, that's helpful. And then just lastly, more of a holistic sort of longer-term question. Given time to close for the P&G deal Hypermarcas closing, it seems fairly quickly, discuss the ability for the business to really hit the ground running o
componenttext: Got it. Okay, that's helpful. And then just lastly, more of a holistic sort of longer-term question. Given time to close for the P&G deal Hypermarcas closing, it seems fairly quickly, discuss the ability for the business to really hit the ground running on Newco, on Coty plus P&G assets, with a specific sort of view on how quickly you can be back in the market do use seek the free cash flow to do more deals.

headline: Coty Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Before we start talking about more deals, as you know, we have a few basically to execute at the moment. So I'm going to refrain from commenting on new deals. The Hypermarcas business is really a critical business enabler, both basically in the P&G t
componenttext: Yes. Before we start talking about more deals, as you know, we have a few basically to execute at the moment. So I'm going to refrain from commenting on new deals. The Hypermarcas business is really a critical business enabler, both basically in the P&G transaction as well as to establish a long-term interesting business in Brazil. And the reason for that is very, very straightforward. The Coty business is very, very small, and therefore, has a very subcritical mass infrastructure. The P&G business is a carve out, and as a result, has a very much of a subcritical mass infrastructure. Just to give you some perspective, the P&G transaction in Brazil would have come with one salesperson. I don't have to tell you that that's not good enough to run a Brazilian business. So the Hypermarcas organization is a full fledge infrastructure business. It has everything. It has the state-of-the-art manufacturing facility and logistics infrastructure. It has also state-of-the-art basically go-to-market infrastructure and a management team, which has proven to be successful in the market from a market share point of view. So as we speak, we are starting to integrate the Coty business into Hypermarcas. And then once that's done, they will get ready to integrate the P&G business. So Hypermarcas is really the main body that is going to be used in order to integrate and the Coty business and the P&G business, rather than Hypermarcas not integrated in Coty. Really, Coty is being integrated into Hypermarcas. Clearly, it gets renamed Coty, but just to be close to clear, from a critical mass point of view, that's where the point of gravity lies, and that's in a very much of an enabler to get deals done as well as to have a healthy business platform going forward.

headline: Coty Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Lauren Lieberman with Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Lauren Lieberman with Barclays.

headline: Coty Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on the Hypermarcas conversation. Bart, do you have a way of framing it for us? Like how -- to what degree do you think this accelerates your vision of what the business will look like in Brazil? Like is it a 3-year accelerator by having t
componenttext: Just a follow-up on the Hypermarcas conversation. Bart, do you have a way of framing it for us? Like how -- to what degree do you think this accelerates your vision of what the business will look like in Brazil? Like is it a 3-year accelerator by having the Hypermarcas piece of what Procter Beauty plus Coty could have been on its own?

headline: Coty Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say it is the main accelerator. In markets like Brazil, if you don't have your own manufacturing infrastructure and your own go-to-market infrastructure, it is very difficult to be successful as a native multinational company because you cannot ba
componenttext: I would say it is the main accelerator. In markets like Brazil, if you don't have your own manufacturing infrastructure and your own go-to-market infrastructure, it is very difficult to be successful as a native multinational company because you cannot basically work with third parties in these 2 areas. So it is a massive accelerator. The fact that Coty doesn't have its own manufacturing infrastructure and has a substandard go-to-market infrastructure, the fact that the P&G business does not really have a local manufacturing infrastructure postdeal and doesn't really have a good go-to-market infrastructure is seriously handicapping, just taking over the P&G business. So it really is a massive accelerator for us. The other good thing about Hypermarcas is, it's a proven management team. They're gaining share as we speak in practically every category that they operate. And so I genuinely believe that this is a massive accelerator for us to be successful even in not in the long term, even in the medium term in Brazil. Clearly, the first job is to absorb these new business -- absorb Coty and then the P&G business. That's the first job. And then shortly thereafter, I would hope that we are going to see an acceleration in terms of the whole platform.

headline: Coty Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you also share that some people have questioned, just given the movement in the real, I guess, the purchase price, and what one pays for emerging market, let alone Brazilian assets currently and current market growth rates. So if you could just shar
componenttext: Could you also share that some people have questioned, just given the movement in the real, I guess, the purchase price, and what one pays for emerging market, let alone Brazilian assets currently and current market growth rates. So if you could just share your perspective on the timing and the macro environment that would be really helpful, too.

headline: Coty Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So first in terms of financing of this acquisition, so it was financed with a cash on hands and the existing debt facilities that we have. It was financed in dollar, but paid in Brazilian real. And it is clear that we have hedged the vast majority of the
componenttext: So first in terms of financing of this acquisition, so it was financed with a cash on hands and the existing debt facilities that we have. It was financed in dollar, but paid in Brazilian real. And it is clear that we have hedged the vast majority of the price at the time of signature. So I think when  now -- so that's the first part of the question. On the second part of the question, the way we think about it is really long term. And so clearly, this is a great asset. It significantly is the merger with the P&G Specialty Beauty Business. As Bart said, it provides the right platform from the go-to-market capabilities, from a manufacturing capabilities. I think we are not ready yet to share the synergies, but in terms of one-off costs and CapEx, it is a significant enabler into the transaction. So we will be able to cost operate with the goods already in Brazil, which will significantly help. So I think you need to think about it from a more strategic standpoint and more long-term standpoint. Brazil is one of the key markets. It's the third biggest beauty market in the world, is the first biggest fragrance market in the world, and it's more a long-term view.

headline: Coty Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just on one last question on the current Coty business. The -- drawing down promotional activity a little bit, I thought it was interesting that the Fragrance business rate of decline was a little bit less bad than I had expected. And that
componenttext: Great. And then just on one last question on the current Coty business. The -- drawing down promotional activity a little bit, I thought it was interesting that the Fragrance business rate of decline was a little bit less bad than I had expected. And that's notable, particularly that you were pulling back on promotions during the holiday season. So could you just comment on the overall kind of market degree of promotional activity if you felt like there was any kind of following going on in the marketplace, it'd coming a little bit more rational or if it's just frankly that your businesses did just fine with a little bit less promotional support than you had expected?

headline: Coty Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, so first in terms of growth rate on the Fragrance business, clearly, there was a differential phasing between the 2 years in terms of the key launches, like I said before, which had an impact on Q2 relative to Q1. In terms of promotional act
componenttext: Yes, I think, so first in terms of growth rate on the Fragrance business, clearly, there was a differential phasing between the 2 years in terms of the key launches, like I said before, which had an impact on Q2 relative to Q1. In terms of promotional activity, I would say, the overall business is starting to get gradually better at managing gross-to-net. And by the way, I am going to retract this number, which Patrice mentioned before of the $2 billion because it's not entirely correct. But I would say the key thing is how to manage gross-to-net, I think, overall the business is getting better at it. And that makes -- I would say, in the general market environment, nothing has really changed. We've just gotten slightly better at it than we did before. And so you see that reflected in the P&L. So market is not more rational. It's very similar. We just got slightly better at it.

headline: Coty Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Steph Wissink with Piper Jaffray.

headline: Coty Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd just like a follow-up on Lauren's earlier question, just with respect to the health of the mass channel globally. If you can just talk a little bit about some of the focus that the retailers have been placing on the beauty category, if you expect that
componenttext: I'd just like a follow-up on Lauren's earlier question, just with respect to the health of the mass channel globally. If you can just talk a little bit about some of the focus that the retailers have been placing on the beauty category, if you expect that to continue here into 2016. And then just secondly with respect to the Beamly acquisition. Just talk a little bit about what we should be looking for in terms of digital engagement, just some of the initiatives that you have planned around some of your core brands and what we should be looking for with respect to some of the digital improvements.

headline: Coty Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would say, mass basically development is very different by subcategory between Fragrance, Color and Skin Care. So as we all know, in the United States, in particular, in Fragrance, the most of the growth is in the prestige area, and is not in the
componenttext: Yes. I would say, mass basically development is very different by subcategory between Fragrance, Color and Skin Care. So as we all know, in the United States, in particular, in Fragrance, the most of the growth is in the prestige area, and is not in the  mass area, part is that because of the way mass basically, in particular, behaves in this category. So I think it's more of a channel issue than anything else. So overall, there it is not doing a great job. In Color Cosmetics, it's very different. So it very much differs by segment. It's not the same. Mass continues to do well in Color Cosmetics. Does not do very well in Fragrance. Retail is focused on Beauty Business. Clearly, that depends on what retailer you talk about. Some retailers are getting increasingly better at it. For instance, the drug trade in the U.S., some drug retailers are doing a substantially better business than they did before on the overall beauty business. Digital engagement on core brands, digital, we are in a phase where we're trying to transform the business to enter to digital world as accepting it, that it is a core component of the entire business. As much as everybody accepts that television, in addition to print and radio, is a normal aspect of doing marketing, we need to have the same on the digital side, and we are on this journey to get the whole organization trained, that digital is just another way of communicating and engaging with our consumers. And this is also where Beamly comes into play. It is there to train and to engage the organization on that journey.

headline: Coty Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: Bert, just a follow-up on that. What is the percentage of spending today in digital? And where should we look for that to go over the next couple of years?

componenttext: Yes, we don't disclose that, and I'm not going to disclose that ever. It's rapidly increasing. That's all I'm going to say.

componenttext: I'll start, and then Patrice has any further comment. So I think in terms of A&CP spending, as you know, we make a distinction between what we really think is strategic spend and nonstrategic spend, the difference being that strategic spend is actually what the consumer sees. Nonstrategic spend is kind of like the money we waste in the office. So clearly, producing a commercial is nonstrategic spend because the consumer doesn't see it. So clearly, the actual airing of a commercial would be strategic spend. Strategic spend, other things would be, it like the furniture that we use in Color Cosmetics in stores or the beauty assistants that we use on the Fragrance business. So those are all basically strategic components. I can tell you that the strategic spend is substantially increasing, in particular, because we're seeing -- we've cut the nonstrategic spend. And on top of that, even within strategic spend, we've gotten greater efficiencies in the media buying area. So overall, the output is substantially increasing. Clearly, I would have liked to see a bigger response to that in terms of top line growth. Having said that, we are seeing this in some brands, but it's being offset, like I said before, because of the rationalization of detail and of certain business lines, plus the fact that on certain brands, we're not gotten yet to the response that we want to have. Anything you want to add?

headline: Coty Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, just on the more long-term perspective, I think the level of investment that in the overall A&CP line is roughly in line with what we want to do on the long term once again. And because of all the efficiency, because of all the indirect procurement sa
componenttext: No, just on the more long-term perspective, I think the level of investment that in the overall A&CP line is roughly in line with what we want to do on the long term once again. And because of all the efficiency, because of all the indirect procurement savings and because of the shift of money from nonstrategic to strategic as well as the reallocation within the strategic spend to power brands, already this is going to hit significantly in terms of GSPs the brands that we would like to push in order to aggregate the momentum on the top line. So the level that we currently have is roughly the right level, plus or minus. And it's more an effort to make sure that we have the right ERI [ph] and that we are a bit more vigilant in the way we shift the money from nonstrategic to strategic.

componenttext: So in terms of the nail category, clearly, there are 2 very distinctive segments. One is what happens at retail, and the other one is what happens in salons. So in terms of retail, which should be the predominant domain of -- or is the domain of Sally Hansen. So the nail category, at the moment, is largely flat. Sally Hansen, as you will know, has done extremely well behind the launch of Miracle Gel, has gained substantial share. We are going to anniversary that substantial share of gain in the second half of this year. So we're going to see a little bit more of a flattening out of the growth profile, clearly in terms of Color Cosmetics for Coty as a result because we are going to index year-on-year. So but the nail category is largely flat in the U.S. for the time being while we are gaining share. Clearly, we are working on initiatives to further enhance category growth and the market share for Sally Hansen. OPI is a very different business. OPI really should not be in a very massive way into retail because mostly salon brand. And like I already detailed to you, we are rationalizing some of the OPI business outside of salon simply because we believe that this is salon brand, and it's a brand that salon owners should be proud of to use.  And we don't want to see a proliferation across many channels of this brand's. Here the effort is very much in terms of driving, both category and share within salons. And there are different segments, which are relevant in that and we're working on innovations, which it's too early for me to discuss. Marc Jacobs and Calvin Klein, so in terms of special retailers, yes, there's a promotional arena out there in terms of the high-end retailers around Christmas as we will know, in particular because online, I don't have to tell you, it is in it's increasing percentage of the total markets. And so that's not changing. As you've seen from our results, we have stayed largely above the fray in this area. And hopefully, by investing, really investing in consumer pull promotion and consumer pull rather than discounting, we are going to continue to stay above the fray.

componenttext: Yes. So our performance measurement going forward is not going to be so much by channel. Is really going to be by category. So on the Luxury Division is going to be responsible for Fragrance and Skin Care. And so we'll be reporting in Fragrance and Skin Care Business. You're going to see in Fragrance business, which is flat to marginally up with basically prestige growing faster the mass. And then you see in Skin care business, which is now growing at a much more modest rate in the low single digits and in Color Cosmetics business -- category, which is still doing reasonably well, growing several percentage points, with basically nail more flattish and with the other parts still showing very healthy growth. And that gives you a rough basically perspective on a category basis. On basically Hypermarcas and other geographies, so I don't have to tell you that still today, and including the P&G transaction, we are still predominantly a North America and a Western European business or European business. So -- which is still the bulk of our business. So we need to, over time, increase our exposure to developing markets. I know this is, maybe most recently not the hardest story developing markets, but over time, longer term, developing markets, in our mind, remain markets with higher growth rates. And this is also why, clearly, we did the Hypermarcas transaction because we believe that this is going to be growth-accretive over time. And will come as no surprise considering our minimal presence we still have in Asia and in Africa and Middle East, we also need to expand in those geographies. So hope that answers your question.

componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining us. On today's call are Bart Becht, Chairman and Interim CEO; and Patrice de Talhouët, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. 
Before we begin, I would like to remind you that many of our comments may contain forward-looking statements. Please refer to our press release and our reports filed with the SEC, where you will find factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from these forward-looking statements. 
All discussions of net revenues are on a like-for-like basis. In addition, except where noted, the discussion of our financial results and our expectations do not reflect certain nonrecurring and other charges. You can find the bridge from GAAP to non-GAAP results in the reconciliation tables in the earnings release.
I will now turn the call over to Bart.

headline: Coty Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kevin. This morning, we'll provide you with a brief update on the expected merger with the P&G Specialty Beauty Business, other corporate developments and Q2 and year-to-date results. Then Patrice and I will be pleased to take your questions.
componenttext:
Thank you, Kevin. This morning, we'll provide you with a brief update on the expected merger with the P&G Specialty Beauty Business, other corporate developments and Q2 and year-to-date results. Then Patrice and I will be pleased to take your questions. 
Our efforts right now are all about creating a very healthy platform for Coty to become the strong leader and challenger in the beauty industry that we aim for it to be. This quarter, we made good progress on that objective, both on the merger acquisition front and the underlying Coty business side.
Starting with the core Coty business. Q2 showed continued improvement in business fundamentals. Coty revenue trends remain muted with a 1% like-for-like decline, and we do expect the Q2 trend to continue for the remainder of the fiscal year as we continue to rationalize nonstrategic product lines and businesses. However, and encouragingly, power brands experienced solid mid-single-digit growth in the second quarter, very much helped by our strategy of focusing and investing in these key brands.
We also continue to show strong momentum in driving profit and cash flow generation. Our year-to-date operating profit grew high single digits, with adjusted operating income growing 13% at constant currency, an impressive growth in operating margin. At the same time, our strong networking capital improvement contributed to significant growth in free cash flow generation. These results show that we can continue to build a healthier and better business despite subdued revenue growth performance.
On the merger and acquisition side, we've made good progress on our Bourjois acquisition. As of today, the local Bourjois businesses have been integrated within Coty local subsidiaries. Also, Bourjois and Coty processes as well as information technology are now fully aligned We continue to see good growth opportunities for this brand and remain confident that it will be margin-accretive to our call of business in fiscal 2017. 
Since announcing the acquisition of Beamly in the second quarter, these top quality leaders in this Digital Marketing company have started to engage and work with the Coty brands on several digital campaigns. We are confident, by bringing in Beamly's cutting-edge digital engagement platform in-house. We will continue to strengthen Coty's marketing and branding efforts.
In addition, we announced on February 1 the completion of the acquisition of the Hypermarcas Beauty & Personal Care business. As a reminder, Hypermarcas is a highly profitable business, with operating margins above Coty levels. This transaction will strengthen Coty's exposure to Brazil, which is one of the largest and growing beauty markets in the world.  We believe it will also provide an excellent platform to integrate the existing small Coty business and the sizable P&G Specialty Beauty Business in Brazil. 
And as announced last week, we signed a new fragrance license agreement with Tiffany & Co., an international renowned jeweler, which we believe will further strengthen our future position as the industry leader in fragrances.
On the P&G Specialty Beauty Business merger, we confirm the transfer of 10 P&G fragrance licenses, including global powerhouses such as Hugo Boss, Gucci and Lacoste. We are making excellent progress to close the P&G Specialty Beauty Business merger in the second half of calendar 2016, and we are happy to report that we have received antitrust approval from the U.S., among other countries. And we are actively engaged in discussions with the EU antitrust authorities. We have also materially advanced on structuring and staffing our future organization and are well advanced in setting up the teams and work streams supporting our IT system requirements and blueprinting the integration plan for the combined businesses. 
And as I discussed on the last call, we believe the new consumer-centric and category-focused organizational structure, our strong brand portfolio, together with our new leadership team, will position Coty well to realize its ambition of becoming a true leader and challenger in the beauty industry and drive profitable growth and shareholder value over time. 
I will now hand over the call to Patrice.

headline: Coty Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bart, and good morning, everyone. Total Q2 net revenues declined 1% like-for-like, with an improvement in the Fragrance segment trends compared to Q1, and a solid Color Cosmetics segment growth with -- in spite of the decline of the U.S. main m
componenttext:
Thank you, Bart, and good morning, everyone. Total Q2 net revenues declined 1% like-for-like, with an improvement in the Fragrance segment trends compared to Q1, and a solid Color Cosmetics segment growth with -- in spite of the decline of the U.S. main market. I'm happy to report that fiscal year to date, the adjusted gross margin increased a very strong 130 basis points to 60.9%, reflecting our continuous effort in driving supply chain efficiencies and reducing discounting activity.
We keep on building a better business even in the face of soft topline trends, with adjusted operating income growing 5% fiscal year-to-date, with a much more substantial 13% increase at constant currency. The year-to-date adjusted operating margin at actual rate grew 160 basis points with meaningful margin increase in Color Cosmetics up 330 basis points and Skin & Body Care up 420 basis points. The Fragrance segment margin increased 20 basis points to 20.2%.
As we discussed on the last call, given the market conditions in our global footprint, FX continued to pressure our revenues and operating income. Fiscal year-to-date, FX lowered net revenues and operating income by over 600 basis points. 
Our year-to-date adjusted diluted EPS was $0.98 compared to $0.73 in the prior year, reflecting, in part, the benefit from the favorable tax settlement  of $113.3 million this year compared to a $32.5 million settlement in the prior year period. Our Global Efficiency program remains on track, as we have recognized cumulative savings of approximately $170 million through the second quarter of fiscal 2016, driven by fixed cost reduction, indirect procurement savings, footprint consolidation and more streamlined operations in China. As a reminder, we expect to generate savings of approximately $270 million through fiscal '17.
On the balance sheet, as a reminder, we closed on a $4.5 billion credit facility this quarter to refinance existing Coty debt with new borrowings subject to longer maturities. As of today, we have swapped approximately 40% of our outstanding net floating rate debt into fixed rates at an owning [ph] cost below 3%, with an average maturities between 3 and 5 years. 
In addition, certain lenders have committed to loan up to $4.5 billion to an affiliate of P&G, which is expected to be conveyed to Coty in connection with the expected merger with the P&G Specialty Beauty Business.
With regard to the merger, the initial filing of our registration statement in connection with the transaction is expected to be filed in April. This registration document will include historical financial information for the beauty brands we are acquiring from P&G through December 31, 2015.
Our strong balance sheet and cash flow generation allowed us to continue to advance on our strategic and financial objectives.
I'm very happy to report that fiscal year-to-date, we generated $517.1 million in operating cash flow and $438.7 million in free cash flow, each up over $160 million versus the prior year. Supported by this strong cash flow generation, we completed our $700 million share buyback program during the second quarter. In total, this fiscal year, we repurchased approximately 26 million Class A shares, and we also returned almost $90 million of cash to shareholders as dividends.
We also announced this morning that the Board has authorized an incremental $500 million of share repurchase program. We will remain opportunistic in the way we use this authorization. It further supports our commitment to return cash to shareholders.
Finally, on February 1, we completed the acquisition of Hypermarcas Beauty & Personal Care business, which we believe, as Bart said, will be a great platform to integrate our current and future business in Brazil. We are very excited to expand our footprint in Brazil with this portfolio of leading brands. 
The execution of the Bourjois acquisition, in line with our expectations as well as the timely closing of the Hypermarcas acquisition demonstrate our ability to successfully execute on our M&A growth strategy.
Thank you. I will now open the call for questions.

So this will be an ongoing process, and it will be reviewed again as part of the P&G merger because then clearly, we will have an enlarged portfolio, and we're going to have to, again, reflect in terms of how we deal with the brand portfolio postmerger. So when I say rationalization of the portfolio, I'm really referring to several items. First, there is a rationalization of very small brands, which sit in the tail of the portfolio. And so there is also a rationalization of some businesses in locations where it shouldn't be. So it is both basically a rationalization of small brands and taking out kind of like business situations and to clean that up. And that is an ongoing effort, which will not stop in this quarter or the next quarter and will continue postmerger.

componenttext: So clearly, on power brands, and as you all know, our strategy is very much to continue to focus and invest in these brands behind key innovations. componenttext: So on the working capital, John, as you know, I'm coming from a company who is familiar with negative working capital. So -- and we are not yet there. So we need to continue on that journey. This being said, it is true that the payables have been the biggest component in the improvement so far. I think there is still some room for improvement in the payables. Now what we really need to tackle is first, the DSO. There is some room for improvement in a couple of regions. And second, on a more fundamental basis, the inventory level. And this is, as you know, more long-term process, which is really about forecast accuracy rationalization of the portfolio that we'll definitely help in that regard. So that's more in the long term. But we are not yet at zero working capital. We are becoming within reach of that target, but we're not yet there. And I think there's going to be some further improvement.

componenttext: Sure. So the gross margin improvement is very sustainable in the sense that it's mainly coming from supply chain. And as you know, we have embarked into a Productivity program 3 years ago. And we have, on an annual basis, steady improvement from the supply chain. It's coming from procurement savings first. It's also coming from rationalization of the footprint and consolidation of the footprint that we continue to do. So these are very sustainable gross margin improvements. On top of that, there are $2 billion sitting between gross sales and net sales, and we are starting to tackle that with some [indiscernible] measurements. This is a long-term process, and we are really working on that. And I think there have been some improvements in that regard also.

componenttext: No, there are basically historical discounts, which have been agreed with retailers. So it's always a combination of different buckets. There are year-end rebates in there. There are contractual arrangements with retailers in there. So it's a variety basically of different components and even across the countries, I would have to discuss with you country-by-country. It's simply the structure differs. If you're interested, we can have a discussion about this at some point in time, but it is a quite involved discussion.

The one thing, which I'm not sure, we will have at that point in time, and I'm not saying we will not have it, but I just cannot tell you today, is the adjustment formula for the Dolce & Gabbana business not coming to us because that's something which would have to be agreed with P&G.
